subject: Re: [junit] Future of testing tools
msgSnippet: Ole, It s great that the pattern works for you.  I like things that work. The only observation I d make is that when language features lead you to adopt a
messageBody:
Ole,

It's great that the pattern works for you. I like things that work.
The only observation I'd make is that when language features lead you to
adopt a pervasive pattern, one that touches every class, it's time to
ask why those language features are getting in the way, and what can be
done.

Michael Feathers
http://www.objectmentor.com
http://michaelfeathers.typepad.com

Ole Ersoy wrote:

>One way to have your cake and eat it too would
>be to use the Class + ClassHelper structure/pattern
>to do the initial coding and testing.
>
>Then a builder creates a parallel project merging the
>Class with the ClassHelper, privatizing the
>ClassHelper's methods in the process.
>
>Cheers,
>- Ole

>>would allow you to

>>You could use it either way and as long as a
>>language has private,
>>people would probably move to one or the other
>>style.
>>
>>I think that the core issue behind all of this is
>>what we choose to
>>think of as the program. For languages like Java
>>which are file-based,
>>that have representation outside the IDE, I suppose
>>there will always be
>>people who want to see those semantics in the
>>source. The thing that is
>>interesting to consider, though, is that if our IDEs
>>can infer this
>>information, is there much merit in the idea of
>>having the programmer
>>specify it? Could it be enough to say, well, you
>>can access whatever
>>you want, but the uses will be immediately apparent
>>when people look at
>>the code.
>>
>>Typing 'private' is a like a little ritual. You are
>>documenting a
>>decision. But, if you have control over the code,
>>you can "untype" it
>>whenever you want to. This is pretty much the same
>>as having the IDE
>>infer it for you. The only way that private has
>>teeth is when you don't
>>have control over the code that uses it. And, as a
>>guy who runs into
>>testing dilemmas all the time, I have to say that
>>those teeth feel very
>>sharp.
>>
>>One way out of this might be to let IDEs manage
>>private the way that
>>Eclipse manages imports. I haven't thought that
>>through yet.. might be
>>neat though.
